This encoded document describes a political cartoon that appears on a newspaper page. Only the cartoon itself has been described; surrounding newspaper text is not transcribed.

div.head: Western United States
div.p: In the left-hand panel of the cartoon, captioned "What Pat would do with him," a stereotypical depiction of an Irishman, wearing a top hat and smoking a pipe, grabs a stereotypical depiction of a Chinese man by his topknot and tunic, forcing him to stand on one foot. The Chinese man is grimacing. The two are standing on a cliff overlooking the ocean. In the landscape behind them a landmass labeled "China" can be viewed, likely indicating that this scene takes place on the west coast of the United States, where many Chinese had immigrated in the mid-1800s. It is implied that "Pat" (a stereotypically Irish name) wants to throw "John Chinaman" off the cliff toward China.

div.head: Southern United States
div.p: In the right-hand panel of the cartoon, captioned "What will be done with him," a white man, implied to be a Southern plantation owner, wearing a wide-brimmed hat, points with both hands as he guides a smiling Chinese man. The Chinese man rests his hand on the Southerner's as he takes a large step forward. Behind them, a sign with a large hand pointing from it advertises that cheap labor is wanted in the cotton fields of the South. It is implied that the Chinese man will perform the labor formerly done by slaves.
